data.title: Best Road Trip Songs for an All
data.meta_description: Our playlist of the best road trip songs is essential for beating boredom and keeping the party going on your next trip.
data.text:
Donâ€™t get us wrongâ€”we really love city life. But sometimes day-tripping to a nearby summer music festival doesnâ€™t quite satiate our need for escape, and thatâ€™s where these classic road trip songs come in. When the urge strikes, itâ€™s time to hit the highway/motorway/whatever for a good, old-fashioned road trip. Of course, you canâ€™t drive in complete silenceâ€”well, you can, but the very thought is giving us a flat tyreâ€”so weâ€™ve compiled our list of the best road trip songs to get your motors running and propel your journey into fifth gear. Crank up classics from the Boss, the Dead and Prince, and even some Whitesnake, as you cruise along the open road, forgetting every care in the world.

RECOMMENDED:

ğŸ¤The best songs about friendship

ğŸ‰ The best birthday songs of all time

ğŸ¶ The best â€™80s songs

ğŸ¤ The best karaoke songs

ğŸ•º The best pop songs of all time

1. â€˜Born to Runâ€™ by Bruce Springsteen

Like Bruce Springsteenâ€™s â€˜Born in the U.S.A.,â€™ â€˜Born to Runâ€™ is darker than it may seem. Embedded in the scuffed poetry of the lyrics is a potent combination of rebellion, sex, disgust and determinationâ€”brought to life by the throaty passion of Springsteenâ€™s voice, the liberating wail of Clarence Clemonsâ€™s sax and the sheer propulsive force of the E Street Bandâ€™s backup. â€œSomeday girl, I donâ€™t know when/Weâ€™re gonna get to that place where we really wanna go,â€ Springsteen promises. â€˜Born to Runâ€™, for all its spikes, takes you there. Itâ€™s a love song, an urban-jungle cry and a perfect anthem of pedal-to-the-metal escape.

2. â€˜Little Red Corvetteâ€™ by Prince

It doesnâ€™t take a B.A. in poetry to figure this dittyâ€™s got nothing to do with cars. In the world of Prince, coupÃ©s are women, horsepower is a pack of Trojan condoms, and gas is stamina in the sheets. The beat takes its time, synthetic drums echoing into the distance, just as the Purple One implores his one-night stand to take it slow, to make it two, three or more nights. Dez Dickerson peels out in the guitar solo, but sheâ€™s the one driving here. Perfect choice of car modelâ€”elusive, American, curvy, risky. It wouldnâ€™t work as a Ferrari or Rolls.

Advertising

3. â€˜Here I Go Againâ€™ by Whitesnake

Been dumped recently? You need to go for a drive (preferably in a Jaguar XJ). Youâ€™ve made up your mind. You ainâ€™t wasting no more time. So tease your hair, don your pleather, and crank up the volume on this 1982 hitâ€”just try not to get stuck in traffic. This power ballad works better on the open road (with no adjacent drivers to judge your Coverdale cover moves).

4. â€˜Where the Streets Have No Nameâ€™ by U2

This anthemic opening track from U2â€™s landmark 1987 LP, The Joshua Tree, is an ideal kick-starter for any road trip (particularly if you're wandering about the California desert where the titular yucca plant is commonly found). From a whisper, the sound of an organ builds up like a spiritual beacon being unveiled. Itâ€™s well over a minute before the Edgeâ€™s churning guitar and Adam Claytonâ€™s propulsive bassline kick in, and another 40 seconds before Bonoâ€™s vocals touch down. By then, youâ€™re ready to hit top gear and wail along: â€˜I want to run/I want to hide/I want to tear down the walls that hold me inside.â€™ Though this road trip song is about Bonoâ€™s vision of an Ireland free from class boundaries, it has inspired countless highway warriors to venture out to those places that maybe arenâ€™t on the map.

Advertising

5. â€˜Love Shackâ€™ by the B-52s

â€˜Hop in my Chrysler! Itâ€™s as big as a whale, and itâ€™s about to set sail!â€™ booms Fred Schneider on this all-time great party song. Admittedly, itâ€™s hard to dance like no oneâ€™s watching when youâ€™re behind the wheel of a Chrysler (or a Fiat Punto, for that matter), but â€˜Love Shackâ€™ will liven up any road trip. If your bumâ€™s getting numb, just whack it on and have yourself a little front or backseat disco.

6. â€˜Sweet Home Alabamaâ€™ by Lynyrd Skynyrd

American football possibly killed off Southern boogie rock. Hear us out. Because of college pigskin rivalries, this song could not be made today. College football is a matter of life and death down there, literally. Iconic trees and people have been murdered over games. Skynyrd was born deep in SEC country: The boogie-rock brothers were from Jacksonville, not Alabama, and cut the track in Georgia. Could you imagine a bunch of Gators fans cutting a tune that could in any way be construed as â€˜Roll Tideâ€™? Yankees and rivals love to mock and loathe the Crimson Tide, but when this ditty plays, every human in the room, no matter the allegiance, becomes a temporary, gen-u-wine Mobile redneck.

Advertising

7. â€˜I Drove All Nightâ€™ by Cyndi Lauper

The irreverent thrift-shop spunk that defined Cyndi Lauperâ€™s persona in the 1980s sometimes overshadowed her killer range and sensitivity as a vocalist, but â€˜I Drove All Nightâ€™â€”from her third album, 1989â€™s â€˜A Time to Rememberâ€™â€”finds her in a different mode. Driven by a feverish desire, she takes the wheel and makes her own way to her loverâ€™s bed. (She may coyly ask, â€˜Is that all right?â€™ but by that time sheâ€™s already done it.) And Lauperâ€™s impressively sustained last note is a perfect expression of the songâ€™s sense of undeterrable yearning.

8. â€˜Fast Carâ€™ by Tracy Chapman

Tracy Chapmanâ€™s beautifully direct 1988 hit, from her eponymous debut album, gives escapism an especially poignant twist. The speeding car and its romantic freedom (â€˜City lights stretched out before us/Your arm felt nice wrapped 'round my shoulderâ€™) canâ€™t be separated from what itâ€™s speeding from: a life of urban poverty, trapped taking care of deadbeatsâ€”first a drunk father and then, at the end, the very driver that she had dreamed might carry her to rescue.

Advertising

9. â€˜Keep the Car Runningâ€™ by Arcade Fire

If thereâ€™s one quality that characterizes Arcade Fireâ€™s sound, itâ€™s urgencyâ€”and nowhere is that more evident than on â€˜Keep the Car Runningâ€™ from the bandâ€™s super noir, grandiose 2007 â€˜Neon Bibleâ€™ album. Based on singer Win Butlerâ€™s childhood nightmares (â€˜Men are coming to take me away!â€™ he pines), â€˜Keep the Car Runningâ€™ expands these fears into a sense of global anxiety, and the certainty that there must be something better down the road (â€˜Donâ€™t know why, but I know I canâ€™t stayâ€™). On its release, the song was likened to prime-era Bruce Springsteen; imagine fansâ€™ joy when Butler and RÃ©gine Chassagne made a surprise showing at the Bossâ€™s stadium gig to bust out the song with him. Warning: You will need to be super-careful not to break the speed limit if you play this song while driving.

10. â€˜Truckinâ€™â€™ by Grateful Dead

Let us pause, and acknowledge the fact that this road trip song has been recognised by the U.S. Library of Congress as a national treasure. Mmmm. Written and performed communally by Jerry Garcia, Phil Lesh, Bob Weir and lyricist Robert Hunter, the catchy, bluesy shuffle turns the bandâ€™s misfortunes on the road into a metaphor for getting through lifeâ€™s constant changes. And really, whatâ€™s a good tripâ€”or a good lifeâ€”if you canâ€™t exclaim at the end, â€˜What a long, strange trip itâ€™s beenâ€™?

Advertising

11. â€˜Road to Nowhereâ€™ by Talking Heads

The gospel-choir intro to this upbeat single, off 1985â€™s â€˜Little Creaturesâ€™ LP, makes for a great start to any road-trip mix. The song celebrates the journey over the destinationâ€”as frontman David Byrne puts it, â€˜I wanted to write a song that presented a resigned, even joyful look at doom.â€™ (Typical of him.) Not every end point is a good one, but weâ€™ll be damned if this march doesnâ€™t have us enjoying the ride.

12. â€˜Gracelandâ€™ by Paul Simon

Road trips are a time for contemplation, whether we expect it (or like it) or not. Paul Simonâ€™s 1986 single is a perfect, toe-tapping exampleâ€”weâ€™re treated to whatâ€™s basically his stream of consciousness on a drive to Graceland with his son after the failure of his marriage to the late, great Carrie Fisher. At turns both nostalgic and hopeful, it runs the gamut of emotions we always seem to experience a little more profoundly on the road.

Advertising

13. â€˜Take It Easyâ€™ by the Eagles

The Eagles took flight in 1972 with their debut single: a quick but mellow paean to the romance of the road, where a world of troublesâ€”romantic and otherwiseâ€”can be shucked at the mere sight of a girl (my lord!) in a flatbed Ford. Cowritten by frontman Glenn Frey and his friend Jackson Browne, the songâ€™s rejection of worry and release into insouciant adventure are perfect for relieving tension on a drive. As the lyrics gently urge: â€˜Donâ€™t let the sound of your own wheels drive you crazy.â€™

14. â€˜Americaâ€™ by Simon and Garfunkel

Add this one to your bucket list: Everyone should be required (at least once) to listen to their restless side, hitchhike, board a bus and go to another city/state/country to find something betterâ€”as described in Simon and Garfunkelâ€™s 1968 classic, which follows two young lovers on a Greyhound in search for America. Take your sweetie along for the ride, smoke cigarettes on the side of the road, chat with the weirdos you meet on your journey, and by all means, indulge in a few slices of all-American pie.

Advertising

15. â€˜Route 66â€™ by Chuck Berry

This R&B standard, written in 1946 by Bobby Troup, has been covered by everyone from the Rolling Stones to John Mayer and Depeche Mode. Weâ€™re partial to Chuck Berryâ€™s 1961 rendition, which matches the 2,400-mile pilgrimage on the L.A.â€“Chicago-connecting titular highway to a T. Who better than the father of rock & roll to accompany a trip past greasy-spoon diners, tiny towns frozen in time and striking Americana landscapes?

16. â€˜Homeâ€™ by Edward Sharpe and the Magnetic Zeros

First and foremost a love song, the L.A. troupeâ€™s jingly-jangly 2010 smash single is also, obviously, about coming home â€“ making it the perfect road trip song. Naturally, the feel-good tune should be played at the end of your voyage, when youâ€™re speeding a bit because you just canâ€™t wait to get home to your significant other/parents/puppy/comfy bed.

Advertising

17. â€˜Going Up the Countryâ€™ by Canned Heat

Released in 1968 and adapted from a 1920s blues song, Canned Heatâ€™s highest-charting single was the unofficial anthem of Woodstockâ€”and even after all this time, itâ€™s the perfect track to kick off a road trip, a steering-wheel-tapping, grin-inducing song that makes you immediately pine for sun-drenched fields: â€œIâ€™m going where the water tastes like wine, we can jump in the water, stay drunk all the time.â€ Those dudes had their priorities straightâ€¦just so long as they had a designated driver.

18. â€˜Iâ€™ve Been Everywhereâ€™ by Johnny Cash

Music has always had the power to educate. Billy Joelâ€™s â€˜We Didnâ€™t Start the Fireâ€™ taught us more 20th-century American history than a yearâ€™s worth of school hisoty lessons. For a CliffsNotes anatomy lesson, we turned to Professor Sir Mix-a-Lot. And when it comes to geography, there is no better musical resource than this name-dropping country ditty, first released with North American locales in 1962 by Canadian crooner Hank Snow. In four verses, 91 places are rattled off in rapid-fire successionâ€”destinations both big (Chicago and Nashville) and small (Fond du Lac, Wisconsin, and Haverstraw, New York). This road trip song has been covered many times and adapted for different regions of the globe, but weâ€™re partial to the Man in Blackâ€™s 1996 rendition, simply because his weathered, gravelly bass-baritone suggests a man who has indeed been everywhere.

Advertising

19. â€˜Hit the Road Jackâ€™ by Ray Charles

Fiendishly simple with its descending piano chords, â€˜Hit the Road Jackâ€™ is sung from the perspective of a philanderer being ejected by his lady. By all rights this 1961 R&B classic should win a prize for being impossible not to sing along to: â€˜What you say?!â€™ screams soul hero Charles to his velvet-voiced Raelettes. Later he complains, â€˜You canâ€™t mean that,â€™ about as convincingly as a cat picking bird feathers from between its teeth. The track's most memorable use in a road trip appears in the 1989 comedy movie The Dream Team.

20. â€˜Holiday Roadâ€™ by Lindsey Buckingham

Hard to hear this seemingly happy little sock hop without thinking of the Griswold family station wagon zooming to Walley World. As its dark video helps to underline, the lyrics speak more of feeling trapped than free. The Fleetwood Mac man was an ace at hiding his boyish ache behind melodic smiles. Which is why this road trip song is such simple genius: It works the same whether youâ€™re chained to a desk and longing for a vacation or finally on the highway, shooting to God knows where with no deadlines.

Advertising

21. â€˜Mr. Blue Skyâ€™ by Electric Light Orchestra

The sweet spot is 176 beats per minute. Thatâ€™s a giddy run, the pace of your footsteps hitting the pavement as you jog home after a first kiss. Though we havenâ€™t tested this, we theorise it is the precise cadence of fence posts whipping past your window as you motor down a highway just above the speed limit. â€˜Mr. Blue Skyâ€™ is 176 beats per minute, which is why, whenever it plays, you have the urge to run like a big dumb puppy dog to a boyfriend/girlfriend, or let the wind blow through your hair at 76mph, as you croon along to the vocoder like a robot. Warning: When â€˜Mr. Blue Skyâ€™ is used without such outlets, it can cause deep wanderlust.

22. â€˜Iâ€™m Gonna Be (500 Miles)â€™ by the Proclaimers

If thereâ€™s one road trip song that can unite everyone in the car in the simple act of thumping whatever surface is near them in time with a ludicrously catchy tune, itâ€™s this oneâ€”a hit in 1988 for Scottish twins the Proclaimers. Fun fact: The â€˜haveringâ€™ referred to in the first verse (â€˜And if I haver, I know Iâ€™m gonna be the man whoâ€™s havering to youâ€™) is Scots slang for babbling foolishly. So now you know.

Advertising

23. â€˜Ride Like the Windâ€˜ by Christopher Cross

Take your EGOT and stuff it. Chris Cross has the transportation trifectaâ€”mega-hits for the sea (â€˜Sailingâ€™), sky (â€˜Arthurâ€™s Themeâ€™) and road (â€˜Ride Like the Windâ€™). People condescendingly pigeonhole the guy as yacht rock (the pink flamingo on his smash album doesnâ€™t help), but heâ€™s truly yacht-jet-and-rental-car rock. Despite its lily-white reputation, â€˜Rideâ€˜ is cool and dangerous. Itâ€™s possiblyâ€”no, probablyâ€”about drug smuggling. Racing away to Mexico with Michael McDonald as the devil on your shoulder. Hearing those percolating bongos, wind effects, electric piano and oily guitar licks, it could fit right on Daft Punkâ€™s â€˜Random Access Memoriesâ€™ album. It remains DJ gold. Call it â€˜Get Unluckyâ€™.

24. â€˜Ramblinâ€™ Manâ€™ by the Allman Brothers Band

We may not have been born in the backseat of a Greyhound bus (thanks, mum!), but for whatever reason, the idea of being a ramblinâ€™ man (or woman) is endlessly appealing. And when we play this 1973 hitâ€”based on Hank Williamsâ€™s 1951 song of the same nameâ€”on the open road, thatâ€™s exactly who we are. At least until Monday.

Advertising

25. â€˜On the Road Againâ€™ by Willie Nelson

Nothing beats hitting the open road, where you can escape the stress of work, family, bills, city life and just be free, man. Just ask tireless road dog Willie Nelson. The Red Headed Stranger penned this 1980 country hitâ€”the ultimate get-the-hell-out-of-town anthemâ€”not in the back of a tour bus but rather, of all places, on a barf bag midflight.

26. â€˜Runninâ€™ Down a Dreamâ€™ by Tom Petty

Some would argue that we could have built this entire list solely out of Petty tunesâ€”but we had to make a choice, and we picked this 1989 single from the song manâ€™s first solo record, â€˜Full Moon Feverâ€™. Not only does it take place in a car, but the tuneâ€™s reference to Del Shannonâ€™s â€˜Runawayâ€™ and killer guitar solo make it a perfect fit for blasting out of your speakers while cruising down the interstate in pursuit of the American dream, your future destination or simply that next roadside burger.

Advertising

27. â€˜Let Me Rideâ€™ by Dr. Dre

Dr. Dreâ€™s â€˜The Chronicâ€™ album arrived on the heels of the 1992 South Central riots. Folks in Compton were looking to escape and could notâ€”and not just because of the traffic on the 110 and 405. This was a cry for cruising with the bucket seats dropped back, slow rolling on a resting-heart-rate rhythm and those G-funk dog-whistle keyboards. â€˜Swing down, sweet chariot, stop, let me ride,â€™ goes the chorus lifted from Parliamentâ€™s â€˜Mothership Connection,â€™ itself based on a slave spiritual. But just because the song hides a deeper political meaning the way lowriders hide a subwoofer in the trunk, thereâ€™s no reason Dre canâ€™t roll in style. Specifically, in a 1964 Chevy Impala shoed with Dayton rims (a.k.a. â€˜Ds,â€™ as in â€˜Throw some Ds on that bitchâ€™).

28. â€˜Born to Be Wildâ€™ by Steppenwolf

The riff, like the rev of a motorcycle throttle, has become so terribly commonplace, itâ€™s hard to imagine what it must have been like to hear its â€˜heavy-metal thunderâ€™ with virgin ears during the opening credits of Easy Rider. Today, Steppenwolfâ€™s monster hit is a movie-trailer clichÃ© on par with â€˜Bad to the Boneâ€™ and â€˜I Got You (I Feel Good).â€™ What was once-tough biker rock is now Viagra-ad fodder. Still, if you can wash out the soundtrack memories of Problem Child, Dr. Dolittle 2, Rugrats Go Wild, et al., the dirty little number still rips, along with a deep huff of exhaust fumes and jazz cigarettes.

Advertising

29. â€˜Donâ€™t Stop Believinâ€™â€™ by Journey

A thousand terrible karaoke performances have somewhat dulled the lustre of this once-gleaming classic â€™80s song, but once it comes on in the car, youâ€™ll be in love with it all over again within seconds. Just donâ€™t use it as a road mapâ€”there is no such place as South Detroit. Okay, there is, but itâ€™s in Ontario, Canada, so you might need your passport.

30. â€˜Interstate Love Songâ€™ by Stone Temple Pilots

The underrated STP (hey, thatâ€™s a fuel additive) was never truly a grunge band. The â€˜Coreâ€™ album was a trend-surfing foot in the door, the American equivalent to Blurâ€™s baggy-riding â€˜Leisureâ€™. Really, the bands have more melodic ambitions. Scott Weiland, as his solo albums and pink fur coat proved, had far more Bowie in him than his peers. â€˜Interstate Love Songâ€™ was the lifting of the veil, when the Pilots announced, Hey, we actually listen to the Beatles, not the Melvins. It chugs along with drop-top bliss, even if the chorus is oddly about trains, not driving.

Advertising

31. â€˜Radar Loveâ€™ by Golden Earring

Appropriately for a song about driving, this 1973 cut from Dutch rockers Golden Earring is one of the best road trip songs ever written. â€˜The road has got me hypnotised, Iâ€™m speeding into a new sunrise!â€™ wails singer Barry Hay, as that bassline gets your head nodding and your foot instinctively pressing down on the gas. â€˜Radar Loveâ€™ also has the best breakdown of any rock song ever. This is an indisputable scientific fact.

32. â€˜Life Is a Highwayâ€™ by Tom Cochrane

Okay. We know how heavy-handed these metaphors are. And how forced the rhymes are. We never said every song on this list was a masterpiece. But we dare you not to sing along with the chorus of this 1991 cheesefestâ€”especially on a highway. Maybe no one ever listens to the song in its entirety (sorry Tom), but one or two â€˜life is a highwayâ€™s are pretty much mandatory. Give in.

Advertising

33. â€˜The Wayâ€™ by Fastball

Alt-rock band Fastball had a breakout 1998 hit with this fast-driving tale of a married pair that ditches its conventional home and family, in favour of a dream life on the highway with no destination. The feel-good, sing-along optimism of the chorusâ€”â€˜Theyâ€™ll never get hungry, theyâ€™ll never get old and greyâ€™â€”has a dark undercurrent: Weeks after their disappearance, the bodies of the real-life Texas couple who inspired the song were discovered in an Arkansas ravine. But all of lifeâ€™s roads hit a dead-end eventually: Better, maybe, at least to leave the driveway.

34. â€˜Californiaâ€™ by Phantom Planet

Contrary to popular belief, the hair-metal power ballad did not die by grungeâ€™s bullet. The hair just got shorter and the trousers got looser. Case in point: this 2002 theme from The O.C. It is emo made only from the emotion of uncut nostalgia. It is basically Motley CrÃ¼eâ€™s â€˜Home Sweet Homeâ€™ for mollycoddled millennials, right down to the video compiled from sentimental tour footage. And it is oddly reminiscent of Al Jolsonâ€™s â€˜California, Here I Come.â€™ Thatâ€™s some feat, finding the common ground between Jolson and the CrÃ¼e. Man, remember when Ryan became a cage fighter after Marissa died?

Advertising

35. â€˜Shut Up and Driveâ€™ by Rihanna

This electro bop from 2007 isnâ€™t a top-tier Rihanna tune, but it still kinda rips. Driven â€“ pun definitely intended â€“ by a crafty sample from New Orderâ€™s club classic â€˜Blue Mondayâ€™, itâ€™s an unashamedly fluffy new wave pastiche thatâ€™s as much about sex as hitting the open highway. Donâ€™t even pretend you can resist it â€“ especially when the chance of RiRi releasing new music any time soon seems to get slimmer with each passing year.

36. â€˜Running on Emptyâ€™ by Jackson Browne

Thereâ€™s a reason this song soundtracks the Forrest Gump protagonistâ€™s famous transcontinental jog: Few pop tunes capture the rush of earthbound travelâ€”by foot, by car or, in Jackson Browneâ€™s case, by tour busâ€”better than this autobiographical FM-radio staple. But what makes it a classic is the ambiguity in Browneâ€™s message. â€˜I donâ€™t know where Iâ€™m running now; Iâ€™m just running on,â€™ he sings, perfectly summing up how the desire for escape can be its own kind of trap.

Advertising

37. â€˜Two of Usâ€™ by the Beatles

The Fab Fourâ€™s back catalogue is replete with songs about travelling around: â€˜Drive My Car,â€™ â€˜Day Tripper,â€™ â€˜Ticket to Ride,â€™ â€˜Yellow Submarineâ€™â€”the list goes on and on like a long and winding road. No Beatles track, though, captures the feeling of setting off into uncharted territory with someone special better than â€˜Two of Us,â€™ penned by Paul McCartney in 1969. There is debate as to whether McCartneyâ€™s partner in crime in this song is future wife Linda Eastman, as he claims, or John Lennon, which some of the nostalgia-infused lyrics would suggest. No matterâ€”an impromptu road trip is a good time whether your passenger-seat companion is your new flame or your counterpart in the greatest songwriting tandem of all time.

38. â€˜Chicagoâ€™ by Sufjan Stevens

Some songs make your heart beat faster from the get-go, and 2005 road-trip song â€˜Chicagoâ€™ is just such a gem, announcing its entrance in a whirlwind of strings and a rush of percussion. The backing cuts suddenly to Stevensâ€™s voice, whispering that most universal human sentiment: â€˜I fell in love againâ€”all things go, all things go,â€™ and then later, another familiar feeling: â€˜I made a lot of mistakes, I made a lot of mistakes.â€™ Itâ€™s this acknowledgement of our frailty, coupled with our irrepressible capacity for hope and excitement that gives â€˜Chicagoâ€™ its electrifying, driving charge. That and the fact it features in the ridiculously touching road movie Little Miss Sunshine.

Advertising

39. â€˜Fade Into Youâ€™ by Mazzy Star

Night driving found a shimmering musical complement in this ethereal 1994 track from dream popsters Mazzy Star. In a rare bit of sonic magic, it seems that no matter how fast youâ€™re driving, the low beats per minute on â€˜Fade Into Youâ€™ always manage to sync up perfectly with the passing dividing lines visible from your carâ€™s two headlights. And a night drive, preferably undertaken as youâ€™re pining for an unrequited love, wouldnâ€™t be complete without Hope Sandovalâ€™s dusk, haunting vocals echoing throughout your ride. Two-lane highway bliss, by moonlight.

40. â€˜The Golden Ageâ€™ by Beck

This 2002 road trip song, off Beckâ€™s desolate, heartbreaking â€˜Sea Changeâ€™, is one of the most perfect and profound illustrations of driving as a means of escape. Itâ€™s best played at night, in the desert if youâ€™ve got one handy, when you feel like crap but have pretty much come to terms with it. And when, as Beck says, â€˜You've gotta drive all night just to feel like youâ€™re okay.â€™ Go forth, drive and wallow. Maybe youâ€™ll feel better in the morning.

Advertising

41. â€˜Scar Tissueâ€™ by Red Hot Chili Peppers

The L.A.-bred Peppers clearly know a thing or two about hitting the highways, as evidenced by a song catalogue riddled with Cali-inspired, crank-up-the-dial tunes. For a journey out on the open road, we like this lead track off the bandâ€™s 1999 album, â€˜Californicationâ€™, due to its lilting desert-by-twilight vibe. The songâ€™s main attraction is John Fruscianteâ€™s wailing guitar solos, which achingly embody Anthony Kiedisâ€™s lyrics about isolation and the twisted, drug-fuelled paths heâ€™s traversed (â€˜With the birds Iâ€™ll share this lonely viewâ€™). Enter tumbleweed, stage right.

42. â€˜Every Day Is a Winding Roadâ€™ by Sheryl Crow

The little sister to Tom Cochraneâ€™s â€˜Life Is a Highway,â€™ Sheryl Crowâ€™s 1996 hit unabashedly co-opts the use of automotive byways as metaphors for lifeâ€™s ups and downs. (Billy â€˜the world is a vampireâ€™ Corgan apparently misread the memo.) The â€˜wackyâ€™ characters in Crowâ€™s songs are often a bit too precious for our likingâ€”in this case, a vending-machine repairman with a daughter he calls â€˜Easterâ€™ (what?)â€”but the chorus always gets us fired up for some hairpin turns, even when weâ€™re cruising down a seemingly endless straightaway. This road trip song works perfectly when your destination is San Franciscoâ€™s iconic Lombard Street, whose residents probably have this tune swirling in their heads 24/7.

Advertising

43. â€˜Jack & Dianeâ€™ by John Cougar Mellencamp

Inevitably, your road trip is going to hit some lulls: Youâ€™re fighting off the yawns, your passengers have passed out, and it's 57 miles to the next pit stop. When this happens, thereâ€™s one sure-fire way to get your journey back on course: Unleash the Cougar. Indianaâ€™s favourite son specialiaes in songs about the heartland, and his crowning jewel is this 1982 chart topper about two high-school sweethearts and the twists and turns of their American Dream. Despite the jaunty beat and an epic drum breakdown rivaling the one in Phil Collinsâ€™s â€˜In the Air Tonight,â€™ the tale is cautionary, urging us to savour those thrilling, carefree teenage years. Oh, to be young, in love and suckinâ€™ on chilli dogs outside the Tastee Freez.â€¦

44. â€˜King of the Roadâ€™ by Roger Miller

Did our dads play this 1964 ditty on long car rides when we were little? You betcha. Do we think they contemplated the potential consequences of making penniless vagabonds sound super cool? Doubtful. Regardless, itâ€™s a timeless everymanâ€™s anthem, and darn if it isnâ€™t catchy. We really like listening to it in our van down by the river.

Advertising

45. â€˜Green Onionsâ€™ by Booker T. & the M.G.â€™s

This R&B instrumental, recorded in 1962, is the perfect soundtrack for an unhurried drive, when youâ€™re sick of singing along and ready to just cruise. Itâ€™s repetitive, much like the open road, but with a steady beat and some soulful Hammond organ to keep things interesting. Widely considered to be one of the greatest songs of all time, itâ€™s received accolades from Rolling Stone, Acclaimed Music, the Grammy Hall of Fame and the Library of Congress. If AAA had a greatest songs list, weâ€™re sure â€˜Green Onionsâ€™ would be on that, too.

46. â€˜Mustang Sallyâ€™ by Wilson Pickett
